text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

ROBERT SUTTON: Welcome
to the inaugural episode of what Huggy Rao and I decided
to call "The ShitFixers."

This is roughly a
monthly series where we talk to people who are
good at getting in and fixing

organizational problems. And our first guest is
my friend David Kelley.

And David, who for many of
you needs no introduction, David is a Stanford professor.

He's a chaired professor. The thing I love about David
is he's beat the system completely. Has no PhD.

He doesn't do publications,
but he has done things like started a company that
created thousands of products

and other changes, IDEO. He's really the driving force
behind the Stanford d.school,

sort of the innovation
education shop at Stanford. And so David is somebody who
has always, to me, pushed

institutions to the
point where I never thought things were possible,
and then that kind of change occurred.

And you come up with
stuff that I still can't believe that
you've gotten away with to tell you the truth.

And so the first time I met
David, I looked it up, 1993. DAVID KELLEY: Wow.

ROBERT SUTTON: So we've
known each other a long time. And my students kept doing
case studies of this crazy guy

with a mustache
named David Kelley. And so one of my
PhD students and I, one of your former students,
Andy Hargadon and I,

we went to see David
in downtown Palo Alto. I still remember. He was in this office with
all this junk in it, all

these products and everything. And we said, David, we
want to do an ethnography. And he gave us the
phone list of IDEO.

And IDEO had about 45
employees in downtown Palo Alto in those days. And you said, here's
the phone list.

Stay as long as you want. And we stayed a year and a half. And then I was an IDEO
fellow for 20 years.

So you still haven't
gotten rid of me. DAVID KELLEY: That's
a good [INAUDIBLE].. ROBERT SUTTON: Let's start
out and talk about IDEO.

Because you and Bill Moggridge
and somebody else started IDEO.

What was the
concept behind that? Because at that time, it was
a very radical design firm. DAVID KELLEY: Excuse me.

Yes. The real truth is that
IDEO started in 1978-- ROBERT SUTTON: Wow.

DAVID KELLEY: --as a
company, Kelley Design. And then it became David Kelley
Design, a very humble title, David Kelley Design.

ROBERT SUTTON: DKD. DAVID KELLEY: Yes, DKD. And IDEO happened later with the
merger of some other companies,

but it's the same
entity the whole time. Anyway, the whole
impetus for this

was I had worked in corporate
America for a while. And I really hated it. It was really bad for me.

They took you and sat
you down next to somebody and say, this is the person
on your team, you know?

And then the project
came from somewhere. And there was already--

the project already had-- ROBERT SUTTON: I'd be
something this big to work on. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. You know, and the
project already

had the solution embedded
in the project statement. So what I really wanted to
do with the beginning of IDEO

was to make it such that
projects allowed the people who

were working on them to come
up with new to the world stuff rather than having it
already well-defined.

And maybe most importantly,
I wanted people to have choice in
who they worked with.

And so I would pick my friends. They would pick other people
that they knew that they liked.

And so from the center,
we built out this team based on who we
wanted to work with.

It's a completely
different environment when you're basically treating
the other person as a friend,

as opposed to as a colleague. I don't know quite
how to describe that, but that's what happened.

That was the magic
of the early days was, when we needed to
do something, it's like,

how would friends
answer that question? How would they decide? ROBERT SUTTON: Yeah. So I remember, I mean, when I
first got there and met you,

I was just sort of astounded. Because you were
a consulting firm. I was used to other firms.

And you said to me, some
client came with an inquiry. And you said to him, well,
let's see if anybody here

is interested in working on it. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. ROBERT SUTTON: And if they're
interested, that'll be great. But if they're not
interested, then we

won't be able to do it for
you, which just sort of blew my mind. Because as you-- corporate
America, you will do this. I mean, that was the
whole model, wasn't it?

DAVID KELLEY: Yeah, sure. We had an early sales
guy named David Haygood.

And he would tell
potential clients-- they say they had this project. And he would say, you
know, that project is not

interesting enough for me to
take it back to the company, you know. And then companies
would try to make

their project more interesting. It's kind of arrogant,
but it wouldn't work in our culture to be
forced to work on something.

And we were constantly
rejecting things. Some people wouldn't
work for the military.

So didn't do anything
for the military. Some people thought selling
carbonated beverages to children--

and so didn't do-- ROBERT SUTTON: You'd reject. DAVID KELLEY: --reject those. And we were lucky enough
to have enough work.

I mean, the question is, if
we were desperate for work, would we have made-- ROBERT SUTTON: Well,
I remember, though,

when there was
downturns, you would take work you wouldn't take
when things were really good. Because-- DAVID KELLEY: Yeah, no. Sure, you have to. ROBERT SUTTON: --you
got to feed people.

DAVID KELLEY: Sure. We were lucky. My mentor, a guy
named Bob McKim said when I started the
company, be careful

because design firms
tend to porpoise, meaning they have too much
work and then they have too little work and back and forth.

But we were lucky enough to
be the design firm of record

for Apple at the time. And so we just had so
much work that we could be picky about what else we did.

ROBERT SUTTON: So
in the beginning, you were a pure
mechanical design shop with a little
industrial design, right?

That's what I-- DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. ROBERT SUTTON:
Because I remember looking at the
percentage of people when we first
started studying you.

It was something like 37
mechanical engineers and 8 industrial designers
or something like that. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah,
well, it depends what

you call a mechanical engineer. ROBERT SUTTON:
Yeah, that's true. DAVID KELLEY: Because
our mechanical engineers came out of the
Stanford design program.

ROBERT SUTTON: Right. DAVID KELLEY: So they probably
had mechanical engineering degrees, but I wouldn't
characterize them

as mechanical engineering. And you brought
up Bill Moggridge, and that's what happened. So his firm was primarily
industrial design,

and we were primarily mechanical
engineering or engineering. And so we started
doing projects together

because the client wanted
everything done all the way. They wanted both how it
works and how it looks.

And so that they didn't
have to fight that out, we fought it out. And we just started to
realize that we were--

it was like an idea
to be full service. We could offer industrial
design and engineering

at the same point. And it worked. ROBERT SUTTON: So
Bill Moggridge, so tell folks what Bill
Moggridge is famous for.

I mean, he invented
the modern design for the clamshell laptop. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. ROBERT SUTTON: He had
the patent for that.

DAVID KELLEY: Yeah, Bill
was a wonderful person. I still miss him every day. Anyway, his firm designed all--

in those days, we were
designing all kinds-- I mean, all of us were
designing new to the world stuff because the technology
was just coming out.

So I mean, I don't know what
the form of it would have been,

but it was easy to do
something new to the world when there wasn't any laptops,
or there wasn't a mouse,

or there wasn't pull-down
menus or whatever. So it was pretty heady
days as far as inventing.

And so Bill was working for a
company called GRiD Systems.

And they had the first-- GRiD wanted to design
the first laptop. And Bill and his
firm designed it.

It was a beautiful case-- ROBERT SUTTON: Oh,
the GRiD, it was like a $5,000 laptop that was so
expensive nobody would buy it.

DAVID KELLEY: But
in those days, you could get the patent
for having the keys

and the display cover each
other to protect each other because one didn't exist. ROBERT SUTTON:
Nobody thought of it.

DAVID KELLEY: Well,
there wasn't any reason to think about it because
there wasn't any laptops. ROBERT SUTTON: And so, folks,
look up Bill's picture.

He talked and looked like
Obi-Wan Kenobi in Star Wars. And he was so classy. I mean, that guy was
such a class act.

DAVID KELLEY: Yeah, I learned
a lot from him, absolutely. ROBERT SUTTON: So
IDEO, in IDEO--

we'll get to the
d.school in a minute. But the thing about
IDEO was there was this point where
you kind of started

pivoting from applying design
to products to processes

into organizational design. I mean, I even remember
Diego Rodriguez, who I think

is watching now,
one of your partners saying he worked for
Steelcase when he was young

and designed a table. And then he was
helping them design their organizational
structure and used the exact same process.

DAVID KELLEY: Yes,
I think that's true. ROBERT SUTTON: So talk a little
bit about that transition. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah.

So our process is really-- we call it human centered,
but it's really around trying to understand what's
meaningful to people

and how to get things to work
well in the people sense. And sometimes that's a product--

in the beginning, it
was only products, so that's all we knew. But then it started to
move towards services.

You can see how the same
process of really understanding what the tray should
look like on an airplane

and how you should
serve the food is very much in the same
understanding what's going on

with the people in [INAUDIBLE] And then we started designing
experiences and systems.

And we found that our process,
because it was so human centered for sure,
but also because it

was so prototype driven, that
we could quickly make something. And it could be a
story of a service

or acting out an
experience, right? And you could just-- all
the things that were wrong
just came out in the prototype. And then we just fixed them.

You have in your
mind that something's going to happen a certain
way or something's going to look or work a certain way.

And then you build a quick one. And you say, oh, my god, you
can't walk on that side of that

because you'll bump into this. And then we can
quickly change it. And so our process
seemed to apply broadly,

both because of how
human centered it was and how quickly we were
willing to switch directions,

pivot in a different direction,
based on our prototyping. ROBERT SUTTON: So I'm going
to tell a little story.

And David knows this is coming. So one of the most amazing
things I ever saw you do--

and I saw you do a
lot of amazing things. But there used to be, at IDEO,
this astounding meeting called

the Monday morning meeting. And still the best
meetings I've ever been to,

there'd be 60 people
sitting around. And you would have
60 people rocking and cranked up at 9
o'clock in the morning.

And these are engineers
who like to stay up late. But anyhow, so what David did is
David did this reorganization.

And what happened, IDEO got big
enough that you couldn't just have one big group. So you broke it
into three studios.

And by the way, the most amazing
reorganization I've ever seen-- those of you who
are watching this

have probably been through
reorganizations where you are told, you are reorganized. And you are now on this team. Well, this reorganization was
he had three studio leaders.

It was Brendan Boyle. Who were the-- I'm trying
to remember who they-- and two others. And they made the pitch,
please join my studio.

So people had a choice of what
group they were being put into. DAVID KELLEY: You could go
in any studio you wanted. ROBERT SUTTON: And people
were really nervous

about the reorganization. What David did-- you
see his mustache. He shaved off his mustache. Nobody had ever seen him
without his mustache.

And he had this line. And he said, so
this organization, it's just like our products.

This is a prototype. It's just like my mustache. I can grow it back. And everybody was just
blown away by that.

And that reorganization,
it worked for a while. And then you did something else. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah, sure. ROBERT SUTTON: But the thing
that I loved about that--

and I still think about
that-- is this notion that an organization, just
like a product, is a prototype.

And that's what we do
at the d.school, too. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah, no. The thing about organizational
change is, I mean,

it needs to be done in
almost all organizations. That's why you have a job.

Anyways, but we
always wanted to be

able to say, nope, that didn't
work a month or two months in.
You could change that. We were going to the studios.

And then we say, oh, no,
that's not going to work. So we're going to have to break
into this kind of organization. But one of the times in our
life-- we did a lot of work

for Steelcase. And one of the big
times in our life was this thing of moving from
private offices to cubicles.

ROBERT SUTTON:
Which is a big deal. DAVID KELLEY: A big deal, right? ROBERT SUTTON: Still a big deal. DAVID KELLEY: Or
maybe not cubicles

was not a good choice, but open
plan versus private offices, right? And we're now almost
all open plan.

Everybody in the planet's
almost open plan. But at the time-- ROBERT SUTTON: There's
a lot of evidence it just sucks, too, by the way. But anyway--

DAVID KELLEY: OK. ROBERT SUTTON: There is. DAVID KELLEY: But
it is what it is. But at this time,
take a law firm,

everybody was in
their own office. ROBERT SUTTON: Right. DAVID KELLEY: And we had
to try to talk them out of their offices and
into an open plan.

It was a really tough sell. So just like everything
else we do, we would say,

we're going to try it. And if it doesn't
work, we're going to go back to the old way.

And in this particular
case, most people preferred the open
plan with some enclaves

so they could have
privacy if they wanted. But it was more exciting
to be out in the middle.

ROBERT SUTTON: So I'm thinking
of that original concept. It was cave and commons, right? DAVID KELLEY: Yes, that's right.

You got a good memory. ROBERT SUTTON: Well, we
used to go out and talk with Hackett, who was the
CEO of Steelcase at the time.

And I think the problem
with a lot of the folks who went to open offices
is they give you all commons in no cave.

DAVID KELLEY: No cave, yeah. ROBERT SUTTON: So
that might be-- so, OK, the IDEO adventure--
interesting, fascinating.

But the other thing
about David is-- and I don't even know how
you get away with this. But he's like a full
professor at Stanford.

He's got a chair. He's in the National
Academy of Engineering. And he's a CEO of a company.

So he's kind of
doing all this stuff. But then you get this idea. So it's, like, 2002.

And I remember
you used to say, I want to start something
that's called the d.school. And we go to IDEO.

It was like Terry Winograd,
Bernie Roth, Jim Patell. And he'd kind of give
us wine and food.

It was really fun. And the thing about
David, I think I've eaten $100,000 worth
of IDEO food in my life. IDEO is very good with food.

And I was looking at
my-- even my email folders have Kelly's Dream.

And then one day you came
back with $35 million from Hasso Plattner, so
we had to do something.

So why don't you to
describe a little bit about the founding of the
d.school and your [INAUDIBLE].. DAVID KELLEY: First, I want to
go back and talk about having

two full-time jobs. I highly recommend having
two full-time jobs. Because in those days,
when I was not at IDEO,

they thought I was at Stanford. And when I was not at Stanford,
they thought I was at IDEO. I could be anywhere, you know?

I mean, I could
be out in the bay. So anyway, I really like
two full-time jobs as a--

ROBERT SUTTON: Because
nobody knows where you are. DAVID KELLEY: --dodge
on being where you are. But the d.school,
so the d.school,

well, first it was a joke,
the d.school because the B School is such a big deal here. And so we wanted to be funny.

And so we called
ourselves the d.school. And we kept getting
cease and desist-- ROBERT SUTTON: Yeah,
every administrator

told you to stop
calling it the d.school. DAVID KELLEY: Except
by the end, they were calling it the d.school. But anyway, the
notion really came

to me was that, if you
go around Stanford, it's just a lot of
people doing something

they don't want to do. The professors are
teaching classes they don't want
to teach, but they

have to teach a certain
number of classes. So they teach
introduction to chemistry or whatever they have to teach.

And the students really don't
want to take the classes, a lot of them anyways, because
they're required, right?

I mean, they would
take elective classes. So if you just look
down from the top,

you see a place where there's
rooms full of people who don't want to be in those rooms. And that made me think I want
a place where people opt in.

They're there
because they want to. And so initially, we
didn't give the students credit for the classes.

And we didn't pay
the professors. ROBERT SUTTON: I remember
not being paid to teach. DAVID KELLEY: And I remember
you complaining about it. ROBERT SUTTON: Yeah, of
course, I complained.

DAVID KELLEY: But
anyway, so that opt in-- ROBERT SUTTON: I still
taught the classes, though. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah,
I know you did. You did.

You taught a lot of classes. And so that notion of
opting in and wanting

to be there for
the right reasons was the thing that
really got me excited. And then we had done
a lot of talking

about multidisciplinary
teaching and stuff. But it really was
we'd go to a meeting

and divide up whatever
the money was and go back and do what we
were doing before. And so it was just talk.

And I really wanted
a place where professors came from
all over the university
to teach together. And we were successful at that. It was amazing. I don't know.

I think there's 50 professors
teach there from all over the-- ROBERT SUTTON: Oh, it's
just amazing how much-- DAVID KELLEY: Every
department, you know?

ROBERT SUTTON: So
I'm thinking of some of the-- because, David,
this was before any classes. You laid out, OK, so
classes are required.

None of our classes
will be required. There was that. Then you had this
concept of sage on stage, which means one
professor like me just

talking the whole time. And then your thing was the
professor doesn't talk so much.

The students actually
have to do something. DAVID KELLEY:
Well, and there has to be multiple professors in
the room at the same time, not

one point of view, at
least two and maybe more. ROBERT SUTTON: And
by the way, just having had taught
at the d.school

and having to struggle with
Stanford, so at Stanford they try to give you less credit
when you do a team-taught class

even though it's actually
more work because you have to coordinate with more people. So there's that. But the other
thing-- and I think

this is getting to prototyping. Maybe we can talk about this and
talk about some of the things that you're most proud of.

Because the d.school
really does have classes where people prototype
products, prototype companies.

They prototype their lives. DAVID KELLEY: Right. ROBERT SUTTON: I mean,
it's just remarkable. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. ROBERT SUTTON: So talk a little
bit about some of the things

that you're most proud of. And it's just right
across from here. It's just such a
buzzy, exciting place. Still when I walk in
there, I'm like, wow.

DAVID KELLEY: Well,
you know, it's a lot more exciting than I
ever dreamed it would be.

And it's been copied
continuously in academia now. And that feels really good.

But the things that
remind me-- there's

a class called
Extreme Affordability. And that was, like, the
first class kind of. ROBERT SUTTON: You co-founded
that with Jim Patell years ago.

DAVID KELLEY: Jim Patell, yeah. And just seeing how
excited the students were to actually go in
country and prototype

something that was going to
help people who had real needs-- ROBERT SUTTON: So the
concept of this class is it's a two quarter class.

You send the students to do
needfinding all over the world, right? DAVID KELLEY: Right. Well, to whatever their--

they're going to do incubators
for babies in India or Africa

that can't maintain their body
weight out in the villages.

And so they're going to
go to those places, yes, and do the needfinding there. And they're just so excited
when the students come back.

And there's been
a lot of companies that have been started out
of just that class in the--

ROBERT SUTTON: Embrace? You're talking about the
one with the baby warmer? DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. ROBERT SUTTON: So
tell the Embrace story because the Embrace
story is a great story.

DAVID KELLEY: Well,
Embrace, the students-- I'll tell a couple
of quick ones. The students came
to the conclusion

that they needed
more incubators. That was because there
were so many babies that

died because they
couldn't keep warm enough to maintain their body weight. And so they went
over to, I think,

design a low-cost incubator. And then just because of
the way our process works,

they figured out that it
didn't do you any good to have an incubator in the hospital.

The babies were all dying
out in the villages. ROBERT SUTTON: So
the problem wasn't to build a better incubator. The problem was to
keep babies warm.

DAVID KELLEY: Exactly. So they ended up
with making something that looked like a sleeping
bag with paraffin in it, and you heat it up.

And I don't know
how many hundreds lives they've saved at this
point, but it was that way.
Another one is when--

I'm blanking on the name
of Terry Winograd's class. But anyway, they went to
Africa to look at fires.

They found that they
found that these villages,

the kind of electrical
systems weren't that robust. And so they'd have fires. And they went.

And I think everybody
thought they were going to do a low-cost
fire extinguisher, right? But when they got there and
really got to know the people,

they were worried
about fire, but they were worried about fire for
a specific reason, which was their immigration
documents would burn.

And then they wouldn't
be legal in that place, and that was really
scary to them. So a fire meant they
could lose their home or--

so anyways, I'll make
a long story short. The students figure out that
that's really the problem.

They get pickup trucks
and get scanners. And they go around and scan
all the documents of the people

have, and they put
them on the cloud. And now, you don't have
to worry about your-- because they teach them
how to pull them down.

They don't have to worry
about the documents burning. It's that kind of excitement.

You can see how that would
turn Stanford students on to make that kind
of contribution.

And there's many, many more. ROBERT SUTTON: And to me-- I mean, maybe let's
sort of back up here.

And we've already
got one question. Please keep asking questions. But let's kind of go through.

Because one of the things that's
happened with a lot of people picking up design
thinking-- we were talking about this in
getting ready for this.

It's all these messy things. DAVID KELLEY: Yes. ROBERT SUTTON: But there's
two or three things that you keep coming back to.
needfinding, rapid prototyping,

what else? What would be-- DAVID KELLEY: Bias
towards action-- rather than sitting with your
laptop in a room someplace,

get out there into things,
and then human-centered. ROBERT SUTTON: Yeah. So the bias towards action
is really interesting.

And I already mentioned Diego
Rodriguez, one of your students who we've both
learned a lot from.

And this is question--
and I've taught with Diego at the d.school. And people say
bias towards action is you're going to
screw things up.

But Diego always asks
this question I love, which is where is your
place for failing? So it's sort of
like the difference

between crashing in
the flight simulator versus the actual airplane. DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. ROBERT SUTTON: So
how do you get--

and you've worked with a lot of
organizations that are really resistant to trying anything. Oh, we might screw it up.

DAVID KELLEY: Right. ROBERT SUTTON: So how do you
get them to sort of move? DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. Well-- ROBERT SUTTON: Because
you're very charming

DAVID KELLEY: No. Well, I don't know about that. But what we believe is that
you need to do something

that Albert Bandura
called guided mastery, a series of small successes.

You can't go into a company and
do the kind of wholesale change

that we would have
in mind when we first got there because it would be
rejected, too different, right?

And so the trick is to
have some experiments,

have some little wins by picking
something that's smaller.

We want to set us
up for success.

So there's obviously
a pivot from where the people are thinking
they should go, what they're doing now.

And if just pivot a little bit,
you get a much better result. And so we start by
having those little wins,

and then people start to notice. And, oh, I want to have-- I want to do things that way if
that's going to be successful.

So it takes a lot of small wins. ROBERT SUTTON: So
it's interesting.

So I mean, a good
example of that-- and I'd love you to jump in on this. I mean, one of IDEO's
biggest clients while

was Procter & Gamble. DAVID KELLEY: Yes. ROBERT SUTTON: And this
amazing woman, Claudia Kotchka who-- we just love Claudia.

So Claudia led this
design thinking movement, and it spread throughout
much of the company

and had a big effect. But I remember she started
with the Mr. Clean people.

Because first of all,
they were desperate because Mr. Clean was just
sort of like-- sales were just

going down and down. And they were so desperate
that you worked with them to help reframe.

And you came up with
the Swiffer, right? DAVID KELLEY:
Well, I'm not sure. I was not on that project.

But, yes, something that
was new to the world came out of the dull
thing that they had.

And so, yeah, I mean,
that's not atypical for IDEO or for the d.school, you know?

You can go-- and part
of it is the leadership being so open at both places.

I mean, Sarah Stein
Greenberg, who's the executive director
of the d.school is really, really
good at getting people

to do stuff that
needs to be done and that they feel like they
contribute across the board.

And so her team is doing
a fantastic job right now.

I just walked across
there from there. ROBERT SUTTON: All right. OK, so we've got some question.

So this is Ajeet - I
don't know where Ajeet is. Sometimes companies have
a hard time getting buy-in from clients around
design thinking,

human-centered process. It feels strange
and wrong to them. So how do you get them on board? You just talked about
doing a little small win.

DAVID KELLEY: Yeah. ROBERT SUTTON: I remember Hasso
Plattner, our donor, the Hasso Plattner Institute of Design.

I'll have one answer,
and I'll see what-- so I remember I was
at SAP giving a talk. And Hasso was giving grief--

I won't name him-- but to another executive. And he said to the executive--
this is the guy who led strategy--

I don't understand
a word you say. I understand every word
that David Kelley says. So that's one thing you say
is you actually speak English.

So that's one way
to convince them. What else do you
